comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: That telephone number was a big hit at the time being so easy to remember.  They were known as "The Sixes" and indeed they were a good company to call.  Great to see the old cars on display, the Ford Zodiac just out of shot and I can't remember the model of the Vauxhall your driver is leaning on

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] And they were still called The Sixes or All the Sixes long after the 7 got added at the start of the number in the 1970s, Sean, I think.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: In the background you can see the big MH for the Mater Hospital Pools which is very appropriate given the court case at the moment on the Govt. cutting off funding to the private lotteries wiped out by the National Lottery.  There was a lot of work going on at the bank on Parnell St./Cavendish Row which has featured in some great discussions on here.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: On the shrine, a quick web search says "It was put there by the taxi drivers around the time of the Eucharistic Congress in 1932."

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The hideous office block now at right (built in 72-74) is called Findlater House.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Absolutely right about the Shrine appearing during the Eucharistic Congress. Letter to the Editor of the Irish Independent on Wednesday, 6 July 1932:
Sir. During Congress Week I came into close contact with large numbers of pilgrims, and almost invariably found that they considered the sight of the old women kneeling in prayer at the beautiful Shrine of the Sacred Heart, opposite the Gresham Hotel, in Upper O'Connell St., one of the most edifying and impressive sights in a festive Dublin. Surely it would be a fitting citizens commemoration of the greatest event in the history of our city to perpetuate this form of devotion by having the Shrine improved and made a permanent monument. Will those interested please forward me their names and addresses so that a meeting may be arranged to discuss details? Reginald Mongan
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I wonder if Reginald Mongan was a taxi driver? Is that how he came into close contact with large numbers of pilgrims?

The Secret Heart is known as the taxi drivers shrine.

The latest plaque under it reads -

"May God bless the taxi driver's, keep them safe and watch over them on there journey's in Memory of Eugene Lawlor Rank Organiser  R.I.P. [maintained by the taxi driver's O'Connell St]

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Some religious folk should not worry - the sign reads "six, sixty-six, sixty-six". There is no 666 in it - obviously the sign maker had the consideration to put in the period-points in order to avoid such confusion.

comment.author: 45618415@N05
comment._content:
I once heard the following (rather dubious) trivia question:

How many statues are there on O'Connell Street?
One - that of the Sacred Heart. All the rest (O'Connell, Parnell, Fr Matthew, etc...) are Monuments rather than Statues.

I can't say I found that answer convincing, but someone might find it interesting.

comment.author: 34001651@N00
comment._content: Re: the invite to my group; 'Atheists who love (photographing) churches'. Please don't be offended if you happen to be a believer. This is simply a group for people who aren't religious, but who still love churches and their contents as essentially human constructions, and who also love photographing them. In the context of the group, the term "church" also includes mosques, synagogues, buddhist, hindu and shinto temples, voodoo shrines etc, etc. i.e. photographs of all kinds of venues and artefacts of human supernaturalist devotion, from any country, age or culture are invited. You can even be a believer and post there if you'd like (but don't tell the rest of the heathens & heretics) This Flickr group's a very broad church, and absolutely all are welcome.
